hints_html: You find the steady state by setting \(\frac{d}{dt}Q = 0\) and calculating \(Q\).
hints_latex:
You find the steady state by setting $\frac{d}{dt}Q = 0$ and calculating
$Q$.
hints_raw:
You find the steady state by setting <math> \frac{d}{dt}Q = 0</math> 
and calculating <math> \ Q</math>.
question: C 04 (b)
sols_html:
To find the steady state, we set \(\frac{d}{dt}Q = 0\).

Hence:

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = 5\frac{\text{grams}}{\text{year}\cdot cm^2} - \frac{0.5}{\text{year}}Q\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} Q = 10\frac{\text{grams}}{cm^2}\end{aligned}\]

is the steady state.
sols_raw:
To find the steady state, we set <math>\frac{d}{dt}Q = 0</math>. 

Hence:

:<math> 0 = 5\frac{\text{grams}}{\text{year}\cdot cm^2} - \frac{0.5}{\text{year}}Q</math>

:<math> Q = 10\frac{\text{grams}}{cm^2} </math> is the steady state.
statement_html:
Dead leaves accumulate on the ground in a forest at a rate of 5 grams per square centimeter per year. At the same time, these leaves decompose at a continuous rate of 50 percent per year.

(b) What is the steady state mass of leaves per square centimeter?
statement_latex:
Dead leaves accumulate on the ground in a forest at a rate of 5 grams
per square centimeter per year. At the same time, these leaves decompose
at a continuous rate of 50 percent per year.

(b) What is the steady state mass of leaves per square centimeter?
statement_raw:
Dead leaves accumulate on the ground in a forest at a rate of 5 grams per square centimeter per year.  At the same time, these leaves decompose at a continuous rate of 50 percent per year.  

(b) What is the steady state mass of leaves per square centimeter?
